chapter.htmlHeader: What else might it be?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Other conditions that may present similarly to rosacea include:

  • Acne vulgaris — usually features comedones, without telangiectasia, flushing, or significant erythema. It can also affect the back and chest, and typically presents in teenagers and young adults. See the CKS topic on Acne vulgaris for more information.
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis — yellow greasy scales on an erythematous base, usually found on the sebum-rich areas of the scalp and face (including the ears, eyebrows, and nasolabial folds). See the CKS topic on Seborrhoeic dermatitis for more information.
  • Contact dermatitis — eczematous itchy rash with dry skin, scaling, and possible vesicles. Often improves if the causative irritant or allergen is removed, and it may affect a person of any age. See the CKS topic on Dermatitis - contact for more information.
  • Photodermatitis/photodamage — general erythema in a sunlight-exposed distribution, including areas other than the face, that may present with blisters and/or scaly patches.
  • Peri-oral and peri-ocular dermatitis — self-limiting small red papules and pustules near the mouth, nose, and eyes, often in the absence of flushing and telangiectasia. Often in young women.
  • Corticosteroid-induced dermatitis — due to long-term use of topical corticosteroids, characterized by generalized redness, skin atrophy, and possible striae.
  • Folliculitis — a superficial infection of the hair follicles, which develop into small inflammatory papules or pustules. May occur in isolation or in association with rosacea. See the CKS topic on Boils, carbuncles, and staphylococcal carriage for more information.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) — discoid or malar 'butterfly' distribution of a facial rash affecting the cheeks and nasal bridge, often associated with photosensitivity, and possible systemic involvement. Rarely presents with pustules.
  • Erysipelas — a bacterial infection usually caused by Group A beta-haemolytic streptococci, predominantly affecting the lower limbs. When it involves the face it can have a ‘butterfly’ distribution on the cheeks and bridge of the nose. It is characterized by red, firm, and swollen skin, which may be finely dimpled and blistered. It is usually abrupt in onset, often accompanied by fever. See the CKS topic on Cellulitis - acute for more information.
  • Keratosis pilaris — a common, genetic condition, characterized by distinct keratotic follicular papules without background erythema, often affecting the proximal arms.
  • Mastocytosis — a rare condition caused by an excess of mast cells in the body tissue, which may present as flushing, itch, abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting, musculoskeletal pain, headache, or neuropsychiatric symptoms.
  • Sarcoidosis — a rare granulomatous condition that typically presents as tender, translucent yellow-red papules on the skin (including the face). There may be systemic involvement.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: The information on differential diagnoses of rosacea is based on the US National Rosacea Society (NRS) expert committee publication Standard classification and pathophysiology of rosacea [Gallo, 2018], the ROSacea COnsensus (ROSCO) international consensus publication Updating the diagnosis, classification and assessment of rosacea: recommendations from the global ROSacea COnsensus (ROSCO) panel [Tan, 2017], the American Acne and Rosacea Society (AARS) publication Update on the management of rosacea from the American Acne and Rosacea Society (AARS) [Del Rosso, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles on rosacea [Culp, 2009; Oge, 2015; van Zuuren, 2017] and on the epidemiology of rosacea [Alexis, 2019].
